Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription: Under direct supervision of a licensed Pharmacist, dispenses, compounds, procures, stores, and distributes pharmacy products. Consults with patients and medical personnel regarding medication therapy. Provides pharmaceutical care for hospitalized or ambulatory patients as assigned. Provides medical personnel and patients with medication information and product identification. Performs other duties as required.

Gatepath provides direct services and programs to children, youth and adults with special needs and developmental disabilities and their families. 

1) Film Class Assistant (2.5 hours per shift) - provide instruction on the film-making process, such as scripting, directing, acting, camera work and editing. Discover your creative talent by learning stage makeup techniques, costume design, special effects and making props. 
    Gatepath Learning and Employment Campus (Age 8-17; Saturdays)
    
2) Hang Outs Assitant (3 hours per shift) - Gatepath’s monthly social and recreational get-togethers for adults ages 13-22 of all abilities, including those with autism, ADHD, or other learning or developmental differences.
    Gatepath Learning and Employment Campus (Age 13-22; Third Friday)
    The Boys & Girls Club of the Peninsula (Age 16-22; First Friday)

Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription:
Paid Role - High school Explainers - If interested in becoming an Explainer for the 2020 Summer Session - apply online between March 1 - March 29, 2020. If selected, an Explainer representative will be in contact to schedule an interview. 

High School Explainers, the Exploratorium’s youngest employees, are a diverse group of students who engage visitors at exhibits, lead demonstrations, and run many museum operations. Some are interested in science; all have a spark for learning new things. In keeping with the Exploratorium’s philosophy, they build their own skills while learning to help others.

Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription: The key goal of the Hutton Junior Fisheries Biology Program is to stimulate interest in pursuing careers in fisheries science and aquatic resource management among high school students from groups underrepresented in the fisheries professions. Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription: Students learn from experts who are devoted to preventing, treating and curing cancer. Students will have access to many research scientists who work in a range of fields at GUMC. Must be 16 by June 1st

Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription: Summer interns come to the NEI to participate in research projects that include but are not limited to age-related macular degeneration and other eye diseases, ophthalmic genetics, retinal cell biology, visual neurobiology, and the immunology of the eye. Students will have the opportunity to work and network with some of the leading investigators in vision research and ophthalmology in the world and expand their knowledge and research experience in basic and clinical research. Must be 17 years old by June 15

Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription: The Summer Internship Program in Biomedical Research immerses students in a unique environment devoted to better-understanding the underlying causes of human genetic disease, leading to the development of novel methods for the detection, prevention and treatment of heritable and genetic disorders. Must be 16 years old. Applications considered on a rolling basis, apply early.

Opportunity Page.OppurtunityLongDescription: The mission of NSF's Summer Scholars Internship Program (SSIP) is to develop undergraduate and graduate student potential through exposure to relevant science and engineering policy, research and education issues and programs; and to encourage students to earn graduate degrees and pursue careers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) fields.
